content.description: This short, challenging route has some fun pocket pulling, balance moves, and interesting dike protrusions. A tricky move to start is followed by easier climbing to a cruxy section at the 3rd bolt where dike protrusions and pockets are used.
content.location:
It is 10 feet left of

Stepping Stone

, look for the glue-in bolts. This is the leftmost route on the Canine Wall.

content.description: Three Dog Night has vertical climbing with good / small holds to a small lip and a thinker exit to the anchors.
content.location:
Downhill from

Master Chief

(if coming up from the Feline Parking lot), locate the large boulder at the base of the climb which aids in clipping the first bolt.

Currently, it is the only route here with Wave bolts.

content.description: A tricky move at the start is followed by easier climbing above. This climb could really use some traffic to clean it up. It's certainly better now that Mike lowered the anchor.
content.protection: 6 bolts, two bolt anchor. Stop at the lower anchor unless you like lots of dirt and loose rock (top anchor is blocked off anyways).
content.location: This is the second leftmost of the Canine Wall routes. It is in a gully feature. Very noticeable belay station with the roots of trees supporting the ground.

content.description:
Stem your way up the corner with mostly easy climbing but a couple of delicate cruxes with a finish out right on a slab.

The guidebook lists this as 5.9, but I've heard it rated 5.11, which seems too stiff. We thought it to be in the 5.10 range, probably easy 10.
content.location:
This is on the left side of the Canine Wall about 50 feet right of

Stepping Stone

. Look for the obvious, stemming dihedral. Also look for a small belay station below the route.

content.description:
Begin with cruxy climbing on great gray stone on small hand holds with ok feet to clip 1.

Move to C2 for a no hands rest at the start of the upper bulgy face by C3.

Clip C4 and move straight up on black rock with tricky climbing past 2 clips to the ring anchors.

Tightly bolted.
content.location: Locate the wooden stairs across from the Feline Parking lot. This is the first route encountered.

content.description: This has balancey, techy climbing on decent rock to a slab finish.
content.location:
At the top of the hill at the Canine Wall, this is 10 feet left of

Brown Chicken

.

content.description:
This climb ascends good, clean gray limestone in a right-facing dihedral, angling to the right. It is just downhill (10 yards) from

Brown Chicken

. The climb requires technique and balance and will feel significantly easier if you are even slightly proficient at that style of climbing. The route features great rock and its only drawback is that it's so short.
content.location:
This is the next route to the right of

Brown Chicken

, about 10 yards downhill.

content.description: Start with balancy moves on sidepulls and then into the long corner above. Climb by stemming, jamming, and moving between the corner, arete, and the crack to the right.
content.location:
At the top of the stairs, starting a few few right of

Jeff's Route

, this is the obvious, gray corner.

climbs.name: Brown Chicken
climbs.fa: Luke Laeser, Trina Ortega & BJ Sbarra, 2005

content.description: Climb the lichen-covered face, trending to the right. The climb gets cleaner the higher you go, staying right of a precarious block up high. A decent outing and well protected, this climb's quality will improve as it cleans up.
content.location: This is located at the top of the slope on a lichen-covered face.
